entry.title: Born to resist the temptation of cheesecake
entry.content:
Main point: Willpower is a kind of physiological instinct, which is like pressure, protects us from self harm through continuous evolution. When the brain and body work at the same time ,we can overcome impulse.

Stress response the instinct to fight or run for life inherited from one’s ancestors

Symptom : rapid heartbeat, chin fight, high mental tension

Information enters the amygdala (alarm system) through the eyes. The amygdala uses the advantage of being in the middle of the brain to quickly transmit information: the adrenal gland releases pressure hormones, the energy stored in the form of fat and sugar enters the blood vessels and liver, which is then transported to the muscles and lungs inhales enough air.

Willpower choose to do something more important and dealing with the desire that cannot be eliminated

Deal with the inner impulse of the body. Instead of speeding up as stress response , the prefrontal cortex should slow down the brain regions that control heart rate, blood pressure and respiration.

Heart rate variability Physical willpower “storage”

Heart rate variability reflects the degree of willpower. For example, people who abstain from alcohol may continue to be sober if they see an increase in the variability of heart rate. In contrate, if the variability of heart rate decreases, they may be impulsive enough to drink again.

Training:

Eat more unprocessed food , food made of plants and less junk food.

Live in a place with good air quality.

Reduce the rate of respiratory (4-6 times per minute).

Keep doing sports which you want to do.

Get enough sleep.

Relax.

British people generally prefer cooking methods: stewing, barbecue and frying. They have unique ways of cooking. They are also particular about breakfast which has a great variety. Roast beef

Fried fish and chips

It is a cheap and convenient food. It can be eaten with salt or vinegar (many British people use both) .

Bitter beer is the most famous beer in Britain. At first, it is an alternative to traditional malt liquor and has low alcohol content.

entry.title: Draft Resolution
entry.content:
Committee: General Assembly Third Committee

Topic: Gender Equality in COVID Pandemic

Sponsors: Islamic Republic of Iran, Japan, People’s Republic of China, Singapore, The Kingdom of Saudi Arabia The Republic of India, The people’s Democratic Republic of Algeria

Signatories: The Kingdom of the Netherlands, Ukraine

​

The United Nations General Assembly Third Committee,

Recalling UN resolution A/RES/52/86,A/RES/52/93, A/RES/74/126, A/74/222, R/48/104 DEVPA, A/RES/74/128,A/RES/74/127,

Recognizing the existence of gender inequality and its negative impact on women’s rights globally,

Aware of the deterioration of gender inequality during the COVID-19 pandemic,

Appealing for specific solutions to gender inequality issues in all fields,

Affirming the majority of health workers on the front-line are women,

Recognizing among those respondents in employment when the pandemic struck, 5 percent of the women are now unemployed, compared with just 2.8 of the men,

Noticing that the COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated automation and digitization, leading to poor reemployment prospects for women,

Recognizing the rise of domestic violence in COVID pandemic,

Emphasizing the importance of solving gender inequality issues,

Reaffirming the necessity to implement suitable policies depending on the current situation of each country,

Part I Gender equality situation during the COVID-19 pandemic

  1. Realizes that women’s rights are still violated, and that the situation of gender inequality is becoming severer during the COVID-19 pandemic including the aspects below:

(1) Health

(2) Unemployment, inequality in working opportunities and income

(3) Unpaid work

(4) Gender-based violence

(5) Politics

(6) Stereotypes towards women

(7) Influence of religion

2.Notes the diversity of inequality situation in each country;

3.Encourages each country to select the suitable policies to implement domestically;

4.Calls all countries to pay attention to the inequality issue and give corresponding and specific solutions;

PART II Health gender inequality in COVID Pandemic

5.Draws attention to the lack of medical and daily necessities for front-line women health workers;

6. Calls upon governments to provide vaccination first and sufficient medical and daily necessities including protective suit, medical masks, alcohol-based hand sanitizer and so on for front-line health workers, especially considering needs of female health workers like tampons;

7.Recommends member states to ensure the provision, through the primary healthcare system, of universal access of couples and individuals to appropriate and affordable preventive services with respect to COVID pandemic;

8.Further recommends member states to expand the provision of counselling and voluntary and confidential diagnostic and treatment services for women;

9.Draws attention to the promotion of mutually respectful and equitable relations between women and men concerning health service needs under COVID Pandemic;

10.Suggests providing more accessible, available and affordable primary healthcare services of high quality including sexual, reproductive, vaccination healthcare through significant increase in investment in social and medical infrastructure;

11.Suggests facilitating coordination and cooperation among governments, departments, agencies, offices and organizations to build a well-bedded system for promoting women’s healthy welfare under COVID pandemic;

12.Suggests increasing participation of women in medical research such as medical trials;

PART II Unemployment

13.Proposes the convening of another Global Leaders’ Meeting on gender equality and women’s empowerment in 2025 to contribute to women’s development in post-pandemic era;

14.Suggests implementing social and income protection mechanisms for alternative employment models to ensure appropriate coverage for all workers in the formal and informal economy, with special attention to essential workers, part-time workers and the self-employed;

15.Recommends to design and test innovative solutions such as portable benefits which workers could carry across multiple jobs;

16.Suggests providing vocational skill training, online courses equally for women and men during COVID pandemic;

17.Calls on governments to eliminate regulatory, legislative, and sociocultural barriers that prevent equal access of women to financial products and services;

18.Calls on governments to make good use of domestic financial institutions, such as banks, and encourage charity fund organizations or companies to provide financial assistance for women in urgent need and ensure women’s access to financial services and products;

19.Suggests adopting gender-responsive budgeting informed by gender impact assessment to ensure that post-pandemic recovery measures foster a gender-inclusive workforce;

20.Calls for investment in supporting infrastructure such as childcare, parental leave and education, in order to increase women’s confidence to reenter the labour market after pandemic;

21.Calls on governments to provide unemployment benefits for fired women, in order to:

(1) Help individuals who have lost their job to sustain a necessary consumption level;

(2) Help creating a more leisurely period of time, so that there will be a bigger possibility for unemployed women to find suitable and sustainable jobs and avoid entering an endless loop of unemployment;

(3) Encourage shifting the business of companies that have been hit severely by the pandemic to those that have been rapidly developing for the stimulation of COVID-19;

22.Suggests instructing domestic citizens to modify conventional stereotypes towards women;

23.Recommends countries to refer to suggestions below when introducing or expanding the use of gender quota, including but not limited to:

(1) The main goal is to ensure that women can overcome obstacles in entering male dominated industries;

(2) Conducting trials in administrative field to which gender quota has contributed more, in order to examine the effects of gender-quota on both positive and negative sides;

(3) Deciding domestic gender quota standard according to countries’ actual situation;

(4) Considering women’s will and how to make up for the novel gap caused by the transfer of women’s proportions labour force;

PART III Unpaid Work

24.Calls on governments to measure the true value of women’s unpaid care and domestic work and its estimated contribution to the economy;

25.Suggests increasing the unpaid work for males who can spare time on family work;

26.Strongly suggests raising the public awareness of gender imbalance in responsibility for domestic care and housework, especially under COVID pandemic;

27.Suggests engaging with men and masculinity as an integral part of securing a positive shift in norms and behaviours about unpaid work;

28.Suggests taking action to correct social norms that undermine women’s agency and access to opportunity for social and economic empowerment;

29.Suggests recognizing and valuing the hidden work that women are doing through gender-disaggregated data and gender-sensitive programming;

30.Suggests redistributing care work between households and the state in the form of government-provided care services for children, people with disabilities and the elderly;

PART IV Gender-based violence

31.Calls on countries to affirm the severity of gender-based violence since gender-based violence apparently threatens the physical health of women, as well as their psychological health, doubling the psychological burden of women caused by COVID pandemic;

32.Calls upon the resolution of ending violence by gender of all forms, including but not limited to raping, sexual harassment, etc.;

33.Draws attention to new forms of gender-based violence, cyber violence towards women for example;

34.Calls on countries to be aware of the different issues each country faces to resolve gender-based violence, including but not limited to cultures and religions;

35.Suggests creating or strengthening institutional mechanisms so that women and girls can report acts of violence against them in a safe and confidential environment, free from the fear of penalties or retaliation, and file charges;

36.Calls on countries to ensure that women with disability have access to information and services in the field of violence against women during and after COVID pandemic;

37.Recommends the methods below to reduce gender-based violence:

(1) Advocating education on gender equality and methods for boycotting gender-based violence;

(2) Establishing laws against gender-based violence, with specified definition of gender-based violence and the corresponding penalties to the perpetrators;

(3) Enhancing the existing mechanisms for women to combat gender-based violence;

(4) Providing hotline and shelter services for women who suffer from gender-based violence and need assistance and consultation;

(5) Collecting data on gender-based violence as a reference of implementation of corresponding policies;

(6) Opposing extremists’ misinterpretation and use of certain religious doctrines;

(7) Strengthening the online censorship of contents showing discrimination and aggression towards women.

entry.title: Garbage classification
entry.content:
My friends and I searched some information about garbage classification. Here it is.

Definition

Garbage classification generally refers to a series of activities, including storage classification throwing and transportation according to certain regulations or standards, so as to transform it into public resources. It has social, economic and ecological benefits.

Why do we need to do refuse classification?

With the development of the technology, the environment is changing for the worse. White pollution, greenhouse effect, desertification and so on are all endangering our lives. So the classification of waste is necessary. In the past, people just threw the rubbish into the sea. It imperils the safety of the marine animals like polar bears. Second, refuse classification can greatly reduce land occupation because some substances in waste are not easy to degrade. Third, turning waste into treasure is helpful to improve the rate of recycling efficiency.

How to separate garbage

The recycling is divided into five parts, which includes the waste paper, plastic, glass, metal and cloth.

  • The waste paper covers newspapers, magazines, books, and all kinds of wrapping paper. It is necessary to mention that tissue is not included because it dissolves in water easily.

  • The plastic covers plastic bags, plastic package, plastic tableware, plastic toothbrush, plastic cup and so on.

  • The glass mainly covers glass bottles, broken glass. However, the mirror is not included.

  • The metal covers different kinds of cans.

  • The cloth covers waste clothes, tablecloth, schoolbag and shoes.

If these things can be recycled, the resources will be saved.

  • The other garbage covers tissue, shell, and dust. If they are buried properly, they can reduce the pollution of water and soil.

  • The kitchen garbage covers bones, pericarp, and leftovers. After dealing with them by biotechnology, every tons of them can produce 0.6-0.7 tons of organic fertilizer.

  • The harmful garbage covers batteries, fluorescent tubes, bulbs, mercurial thermometer, overdue pedicure and so on. All of them contain toxic substances, so they are recycled specially.

entry.title: History
entry.content:
History

ROME PERIOD

  • Early civilization

About 700 B.C., the Celts, who lived in Western Europe, continued to move into the British Isles. One of them was called the Britons, which the name Britain probably came from.

  • Roman invasion

In 43 A.D., Britain transformed it into a province of the Roman Empire. In 409, the Roman garrison was forced to withdraw from Britain, and Rome’s rule over Britain came to an end.

MEDIEVAL TIMES

  • Anglo Saxon

At the beginning of the 5th century, after the withdrawal of the Romans, the Anglo Saxons and the Jutes conquered Britain. The angles called Britain “angland”.(Homophonic English, the origin of the English name)

At the beginning of the 7th century, the land became private property, and aristocrats, landowners, dependent farmers and slaves appeared, which was generally considered to be the beginning of the feudal process in British society. Christianity was introduced into England at the end of the 6th century.

  • Danish invasion

During the Danish occupation, the process of British feudalization accelerated.

  • Norman Conquest

William, Duke of Normandy in France, led his army to invade in 1066. In October of the same year, he entered London and was crowned as King William 1.

The powerful monarchy established by William after his conquest played a positive role in consolidating the feudal order. (Great Charter)

  • Watt Taylor Uprising

In 1380, King Richard II increased the poll tax in order to collect the expenses of the Hundred Years’ War, which led to the break of uprising in May 1381, organized by the bricklayer watt Taylor. Although the uprising failed, it cracks down the feudal serfdom in England. In the 15th century, the feudal lord class changed– new aristocrats appeared, and capitalist management was adopted.

  • Hundred Years’ War

Britain and France fought off and on for 116 years during the Black Death epidemic. Under the double attack of war and epidemic disease, British economy suffered a lot, but it also made England’s nationalism rise. By the end of the war, Britain had embarked on the road of centralization.

PRIMITIVE ACCUMULATION OF CAPITA

Enclosure movement, overseas plunder and trade are important methods of British capital primitive accumulation. England and Wales merged in 1536. From 1577 to 1580, the circumnavigation shocked Europe. In 1588, Britain defeated the Spanish Armada.

AUTOCRATIC MONARCHY

In 1603, King James VI of Scotland carried on the British throne. From the second half of the 16th century to the first half of the 17th century, the capitalist economy developed rapidly.

The Glorious Revolution broke out in 1688-1689 and the bill of rights announced laid the base of British constitutional monarchy. In 1707, it merged with Scotland.

THE RENAISSANCE

Compared with the European continent, renaissance took place later in Britain but came first. In this period, Shakespeare, bacon and Harvey are the most outstanding in the fields of art, literature and science.

INDUSTRIAL REVOLUTION

Britain is the first industrialized country in the world. It was the first to make many scientific discoveries and inventions.

COLONIAL EXPANSION

After the merger of Ireland in 1801, Britain was named the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland. It became the largest global colonial empire in history, taking up a quarter of the world’s population and land area at that time. After the kingdom of Spain in the 16th century, it was known as “the sun never sets the Empire”.

In the middle of the 19th century, Britain launched two Opium Wars to invade China, occupied Hong Kong Island and participated in the suppression of the Taiping Revolution. In 1876, after Queen Victoria was crowned Queen of India, Britain was also known as the British Empire.

WORLD WAR

After the 1870s, Britain lost its industrial monopoly. In the early 20th century, Germany became its competitor. Britain gave up the “splendid isolation” foreign policy pursued in the 19th century to form the agreement with France and Russia after 1907. In August 1914, First World War broke out. In 1917, Britain defeated Germany’s “unrestricted submarine warfare” and maintained its sea control power.

In September 1939, World War II broke out and Britain declared war on Germany. Churchill came to power in April 1940. From July to September 1940, the British air force attacked the enemy in the “Air Battle of Britain” launched by Germany. In June 1944, British and American troops landed in Normandy. France and Germany surrendered on May 8, 1945. Yalta conference was held from 4 to 11 in February, 1945.

POSTWAR PERIOD

  • Britain participated in drawing up and accepting the Marshall Plan in 1947 and received a large amount of aid from the United States and its economy gradually recovered.

  • It joined the European Community in January 1973.

  • After the 1979 election, the conservative party, Ms. Thatcher, was in power.

  • After the decolonization in the 20th century, British Overseas Territories gradually became independent, and most of them formed a peace organization with Britain–the Commonwealth of Nations.

  • On September 18, 2014, 4 million permanent residents of Scotland held a referendum to decide whether Scotland would remain in the UK.

  • On October 28, 2016, the UK was elected to the UN Human Rights Council for a term from 2017 to 2019.

  • On January 31, 2020, Britain officially left Europe and ended its 47 year EU membership.

entry.title: Personal goal
entry.content:
I set a personal goal for myself which was to pass IELTS with an overall band score of 6.5 as I will apply for university with this score

The preparation took over 4 months of hard work involved doing past papers and so on. With the help of my teachers, I completed and corrected all the daily tasks according to the plan made by my class advisor. Then my teachers suggested a different way of collating my mistakes to make it easier to learn from them and this suggestion did help me a lot. As a result, I have more free time to pursue my own personal interests.

entry.title: How to prove the sum of interior angles of triangles equals to 180 degrees
entry.content:
How to prove the sum of interior angles of triangles equals to 180 degrees

Draw line DE which passes point C and parallels to line AB
∵DE//AB
∴∠B=∠1,∠A=∠2
∵point D,C,E are all on the straight line DE
∴∠DCE=180°
∴∠A+∠B+∠BCA=180°
∴The sum of interior angles of triangles equals to 180°

Draw line CE which parallels to line AB

∵CE//AB

∴∠A=∠1,∠B=∠2

∵point B,C,D are all on the straight line BD

∴∠BCD=180°

∴∠A+∠B+∠BCA=180°

∴The sum of interior angles of triangles equals to 180°

entry.title: How do microphones work
entry.content: When a person speak or sing to a microphone, the sound wave makes the diaphragm of the microphone vibrate. So the coil which is connected to diaphragm cuts the magnetic induction line in the magnetic field and generates current. Moreover,the magnitude of the current depends on the loudness of the sound. In Physics,we call that electromagnetic induction.

1.Choose one aspect of gender inequality, and list more than TWO evidences to back up your statement.

There are gender disparity in political empowerment.

Evidence 1:Women in national parliaments are also severely underrepresented. Till April 2021, of 46204 parliaments seats across the world, only 25.5% (11770) of all national parliamentarians are women. The website where you find this: http://data.ipu.org/women-ranking?month=4&year=2021

Evidence 2:Some reports say that very few women have served as head of state in the highest political position. Only 22 countries have had women leaders as the head of state or government, and there has never been a woman in the highest position in other 119 countries. The website where you find this: https://www.unwomen.org/en/about-us/ about-un-women.

2.Find one treaty/ protocol/ declaration/ collective action plan signed based on UN resolution or regional consensus. State your opinion to it, like advantage/ disadvantage, historical milestone, leading to some act or so.

The United Nations General Assembly passed resolution on COVID-19. The resolution was passed by 169 out of 193 countries. Only the United States and Israel objected it. Member states strengthen international cooperation, solidarity and mutual assistance to fight against COVID-19. The resolution stated that international cooperation, multilateralism, solidarity and mutual assistance are the only ways for the world to effectively respond to global crises such as COVID-19. It called on all countries to treat everyone equally. The resolution supported the global ceasefire initiative proposed by the UN Secretary-General, paid close attention to the impact of the epidemic on areas of armed conflict, and continued to support UN peacekeeping operations. The resolution urged member states, political leaders and religious leaders to not only promote tolerance and unity but also oppose violence and discrimination. It also urged member states to strengthen health systems and social care systems. Moreover, it urged member states and other stakeholders to deal with the direct social and economic impact of COVID-19. This resolution cracked down on unilateralism, protectionism and hegemonism. At the same time, it promoted international cooperation and encouraged the practice of multilateralism. Many countries cooperated to effectively control the epidemic. For example, Russia assisted Wuhan with personal protection and medical supplies many times. Pakistan, with its underdeveloped economy and low level of medical care, also solicited medical supplies from public hospitals across the whole country to provide assistance to our country, which was very touching. Our country has also donated supplies to many countries and sent teams of medical experts.

3.Choose ONE delegation you prefer and state reasons. This answer will be the critical reference to delegation arrangement.

My favourite United Nations delegation is the Chinese delegation. Because the Chinese delegation can always put forward creative initiatives that are beneficial to the world according to current events. entry.title: Position Paper
entry.content:
Delegate: Zhao Jie
Delegation: Japan
Committee: The Third Committee of the United Nations General Assembly
Topic: Gender equality in COVID pandemic
School: Jinling High School

Introduction

The patriarchal clan society led to gender discrimination as most men had an advantage over women in physical strength, however, gender inequality still exists these days. Since the spread of the COVID-19, some situations even have made it more serious. For example, many companies tend to fire female employees to ensure their profits. This has caused dissatisfaction among many people.
As the builders and contributors of society, women have the right to fight for and take back the opportunities they should have. Moreover, eliminating gender discrimination can improve social civilization, increase productivity, and promote the emergence of more talents. So it is important for us to help women and take actions to eliminate gender inequality.

Past actions

The United Nations passed The Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women at the General Assembly on December 18, 1979, and it entered into force in September 1981. It is an international convention on the rights of women and promotes the feminist movement through international treaties. It is also an important international human rights instrument formulated by the United Nations to eliminate discrimination against women and strive for gender equality. The convention establishes rules to protect women’s rights in politics, law, work, education, medical services, business activities and family relations. UN Women claimed that many women’s industries were hit hard by the COVID-19. Women are increasingly facing the difficulty of making a living. There will be more than 47 million women and children living below the poverty line in the world. At the same time, UN Women called on all the countries to strengthen solidarity and cooperation to promote gender equality and women’s empowerment.
Since Japanese companies use the annual merit-based wage system for their wages, companies are tend to recruit male employees. In order to solve the serious gender discrimination of Japanese companies in recruiting employees, Japan has banned filling in gender and pasting photos on resumes.

Position of Japan

Due to the influence of Japanese traditional culture, there is still serious gender discrimination in Japanese society. The COVID-19 has made gender discrimination harming Japanese women’s lives more, especially those who living at the bottom of society. Gender inequality has no benefits to the development and civilization progress, so Japan supports the elimination of gender discrimination. As a developed country, Japan will actively take equal rights measures.
On December 18, the World Economic Forum (WEF) released the “2018 Global Gender Difference Report”. Among the 149 countries surveyed, Japan ranked 110th (with a total score of 0.662) and was still the last place in the G7 group. The main reason for Japan’s low ranking is its low scores in the economic and political sectors. Excessive income gap between men and women (103, score 0.527) and large gap in the number of men and women in management positions (129, score 0.152) have a greater impact. In the education and health care parts, Japan has achieved a high score of nearly full score.
According to this report, Japan will investigate if companies treat male and female employees differently and introduce policies to narrow the wage gap between male and female employees to ensure women’s income. At the same time, the government will stipulate the ratio of male and female employees in enterprises to solve the problem of high unemployment among women. Japan will also encourage women to participate in politics and improve women’s social status. At the same time, Japan will maintain equality in education and health. We will also fight against those who think that women should do housework to take care of children and the elderly for unpaid work in home. Develop social discussions on a larger scale and awaken people’s awareness to achieve gender equality is the result that beneficial to the public.

entry.title: The first competition of my life
entry.content:
An event which sparked a period of personal growth and a new understanding of myself was my first participation in the musical instrument competition held by my primary school.

I used to be a shy girl. Although I enjoyed playing a kind of traditional chinese musical instrument called the guzheng, I was not brave enough to play it in front of the public. As a result, almost no one knew that I could play the guzheng apart from my relatives and teachers.

However, this situation changed when I was in the third grade. My music teacher thought that I should be willing to take challenges to show everyone my unique skills and be more confident, so she recommended me to the school to take part in the instrument competition. I wanted to refuse, but my parents also encouraged me to take this rare opportunity. Finally, I made up my mind to prepare for this competition seriously as I did not want to let down the people in my life who have always supported me. During the preparation for this competition, I was still very nervous and anxious. However, my parents told me that the meaning and purpose of the competition was not only to win prizes, but also to help me become a better person through this kind of experience. From then on, I started to enjoy practicing playing the guzheng and felt happy because both my ability and my confidence improved. After several months of hard preparation, I won the second prize. I found I was able to achieve the success which I had wanted.

Through my experience of this event, I changed from being timid and introverted to being brave, confident and able to cherish any opportunities in my life. The music I played at the ten-year celebration of junior school was appreciated by my classmates and teachers. I am now a member of the high school symphonic band. I also take an active part in other club activities or subject competitions. I really enjoy the feeling of self-improvement.

entry.title: What is willpower? & Why is willpower important?
entry.content:
MAIN POINT: Willpower is actually three forces called “I do not want to do”, “I want to do” and “What I want to do” .They work together to make ourselves better.

Principles of Neurology

The prefrontal cortex (a kind of grey matters) makes us to do things which is more difficult but right .

The stronger the cell activity, the stronger the ability to take action and resist temptation.

I don’t want to: control your impulsivity
What I want to do: deal with boring, difficult and stressful work
I want to: record goals, desires and what you really want

Willpower challenge (know yourself properly)

We use cookie monsters, critics and procrastinators to describe people who enjoy pleasure in good time, like to complain or always do not want to work respectively.

When we are aware of the existence of the negative self, it is actually helpful to wake up the wise self (willpower). It’s wrong to want to get rid of the negative self (primitive impulse). Because getting rid of desire leads to depression and getting rid of fear leads to injury.

The key to success
  • Learn how to use primitive instinct instead of resisting.
  • Know that the self-control system and survival instinct may conflict or cooperate with each other (want to buy something but give up for its high price).
  • The brain can be reshaped according to the requirements of people. With a certain amount of training, the density of certain areas in the brain will increase. As a result, there will be more grey matter.
**Training methods (Meditation) **

Meditation can improve self-control and attention. At the same time, it can also reduce pressure, restrain the impulse and improve your self-awareness ability.

(at least 5 minutes a day, focus on the breath itself)

Summary

There are several themselves in the brain of modern people. They compete with each other, trying to control our ideas. Each willpower challenge is a self game. The purpose of doing the willpower challenge is to let a better self control our bodies. In this way, we can choose to do right things.

entry.title: Working Paper 2
entry.content:
Sponsors: China, India, Singapore, Japan

Impacts of COVID pandemic on women

Recognizing impacts on women medical health are urgent, as majority of health workers on the front-line are women, leading women to higher risk in exposing themselves to the virus than men，

Fully aware of the fact that COVID pandemic has intensified women unemployment, as women are often considered as the family care character when it comes to a crisis like pandemic, which forces women to abandon their career jobs，

Noticing the lack of medical and daily necessities for front-line women health workers，

Realizing that the social norm and policies such as nationally universal healthy insurance are not totally suitable for underdeveloped countries，

Recognizing that the spread of the epidemic amplifies the gender gap, threatens the women’s health rights:

Physiological:

1.Male preference (according to statistics, female vaccination rate is only 66.4% of male)；

2.The family violence psychology；

3.Increased psychological stress among Women (Suicide rate rises in Japan)；

4.Impermanence Housework often increases；

Women’s right to health, long-term impairment, we are concerned about the following issues:

1.There is no legal support for health products in Asia-Pacific countries;

2.Under the influence of religious factors, female physiological organs are mutilated;

3.Sexist online violence and verbal violence;

4.Sexual violence, harassment；

5.Women’s burden of childcare，

Solutions:

Encourages male to participate in family healthcare to balance the disproportionate contributions between men and women to childcare, housework, etc;

Suggests increasing participation of women in medical research, for instance, in medical trials. Chinese doctor Li Lanjuan can serve as a model in women’s contribution to medical health;

Calls on states with sufficient financial abilities to increase funding to countries which lack medical and economic power, in order to ensure that women and girls can access high quality, gender-appropriate healthcare;

Suggests governments enabling women to participate more in political decision-making, contributing the wisdom of women to societies;

Recommends governments to strengthen legislation on gender-based violence, enhance reporting privacy mechanism, simplify of filing procedures, and increase punishment measures;

Suggests mandatory maternity leave for men to shoulder the burden of childcare with women;

China proposes the convening of another Global Leaders’ Meeting on Gender Equality and Women’s Empowerment in 2025 to contribute to women’s development in the post-pandemic era;

China proposes the convening of an annual conference under the framework of UN Women, which gathers women from all over the world to express and communicate on their opinions and prospects on gender parity.

Effects of religious factors on women’s health in this pandemic

Noticing the first session mentioned some negative effects in this pandemic, but there are still a lot of problems in figuring out these adverse impacts. India personally thinks that we should not only explain the reasons and consequences of these inactive effects. India partly agrees with that some delegates said that education could solve the problem of religion on women’s health in this pandemic,but there should be more pragmatic actions. From Indian perspective, above all, education and religion have closely linked, so it is untoward for India to change this situation during a very short period. Secondly, for the reason that in this pandemic, India presented a policy which stopped schools,education institutions and research institutions. As a result, use education to solve religious factors in this pandemic is not actual;

Noticing the statement of Iranian delegate that owing to Iranian common belief in Islam, Iranian domestic health system are not allowed to achieve certain gender equality goals in underdeveloped areas. And Iran calls for assistance to improving dispensation in domestic underdeveloped areas.

Outlook

We consider the successful resolution of health issue as a prerequisite for further discussion of other issues.

Noticing the first session mentioned that health issue in both physical and mental aspects of female medical staff and civilians in this pandemic.

From the aspect of physiology, we noticed two factors, which are seedling tilt and family violence.

From the aspect of the mental health, we see obviously that the pressure of women had an enormous increase, for instance,the suicide rates of Japan’s women. As a research indicated, physical factors partly led to psychological problems. Besides these, women’s health in our daily life is also very important. At present,there are no legal support for sanitary products in Asia-Pacific countries.

Moreover, influenced by religious factors, female physiological organs were mutilated. Cyber-violence, verbal violence, sexual violence, harassment, unequal treatment within marriage such as cheating and sexual violence also influenced women a lot in this pandemic.

According to this situation, we propose some measures to solve it. Firstly, we should enforce an adequate criminal justice response plays an important role. Secondly, listen to women facing intersection forms of discrimination is a method to let women understand they T are taken as seriously as the men. Thirdly , increasing the number of women in leadership gives equal rights for both women and men on deciding significant things in the society. Last but not least, we should listen to girls to know their thoughts from a young age.

entry.title: Working Paper 4
entry.content:
Sponsors: China, India, Iran, Japan,Singapore

Part I Effects of pandemic on women employment

i. Recognizing among those respondents in employment when the pandemic struck, 5 percent of the women are now unemployed, compared with just 2.8 of the men.

ii. Noticing that LinkedIn data shows that the number of women in leadership positions has dropped significantly, leading to a reversal of progress in multiple industries in one to two years.

iii. Noticing that the COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated automation and digitization, and intensified the damage to the labour market. Due to the gradual increase in “two shifts” and the combined effects of occupational segregation and other labour market dynamics, this epidemic is likely to have a traumatic impact on women’s future economy and may lead to poor reemployment prospects.

Part II Effects of pandemic on women income

i. Aware of that women have seen their earnings decline almost two-thirds more sharply than man, dropping by 16.5 percent on average since the pandemic began, compared with a drop of 10.1 percent for men.

ii. Noticing the situation as regards personal disposable income is almost identical at the global level. In every market surveyed, women report a steeper decline in the ability to pay for non-essential goods and services than men, ranging from 73% in South Africa to 19% in the UK.

iii. Realizing that the pandemic has shown that quarantine measures greatly weakened women’ s economic capacity and increased poverty rate and food insecurity of women living in poor regions.

iv. Further realizing that due to deep-rooted structural reasons, women’s income is 16% lower than men’s at global average level, and the wage gap in some countries can reach 35%.

Part III Measures to alleviate women unemployment and loss of income in pandemic

i. Implement social and income protection mechanisms for alternative employment models to ensure appropriate coverage for all workers in the formal and informal economy, with special attention to essential workers, part-time workers and the self employed.

ii. Design and test innovative solutions such as portable benefits which workers could carry across multiple jobs.

iii. Eliminate regulatory, legislative, and sociocultural barriers that prevent equal access of women to financial products and services.

iv. Call on governments to cooperate with UNICEF, UN Women, UNESCO, make good use of domestic financial institutions, such as banks, and encourage charity fund organizations or companies to provide financial assistance for women in urgent need and ensure women’s access to financial services and products.

v. Adopt gender-responsive budgeting informed by gender impact assessment to ensure that pandemic recovery measures foster a gender-inclusive workforce.

vi. Suggest instructing domestic citizens to modify conventional stereotypes towards women.

Part III Controversies on the gender quota

Noting the different attitudes towards the solution of gender quota;

i. Supportive of gender quota

Countries such as New Zealand is supportive of gender quota. The reason given is that gender quota contributes to the adjustments to the gender percentages in certain occupations, thus contributing to the process of gender equality in economics. To be more specifically, the supportive countries attach importance to the percentage of gender in employment, which is regarded by the supportive countries as a sign of gender equality in employment.

ii. Opposite to gender quota

Countries like Iran and Lichtenstein are opposite to gender quota. For instance, the reasons given by Iran are that the choices of employment by citizens, whether males or females, shouldn’t be interfered by mandatory standards of gender percentage of employment. Also, Iran reminds that gender quota is a mandatory standard controlling the gender percentage in employment intentionally, yet this can’t solve the fundamental issue of gender equality. For instance, the fundamental factor causing gender equality in Iran is conventional perspectives towards women. To ensure the successful implementation of gender equality, those stereotypes should be corrected first, or the execution of gender quota is just limited to balancing the percentages of gender in employment, rather than solve the problem in a sustainable way.

-Reminding that gender quota is not a mandatory method for the international society;

-Encouraging countries holding different views towards gender quota to choose the policy that suits the domestic situation of the nation, including but not limited to gender quota.

ii. To reach a consensus

China advocates countries which have not implement gender-quota but hope to attempt this policy can conduct trials in areas like administration to test the effects of gender-quota. And China suggests governments organizing domestic assessment experts on political effectiveness to judge if gender-quota is completely suitable. If not, governments could take other measures and improve current policies to promote women participation in decision-making.

Part IV Outlook

Outlook

Noticing the violence against women during the is a commonplace, we divide into three parts to carry out a profound discussion. The three parts are domestic violence and society violence, sexual violence, and the laws and suggestions respectively.

Domestic violence and society violence

The control of the epidemic requires people to avoid gathering so isolation have increased the possibility of domestic violence. With people confined to their homes under the pandemic, many more women reached out for help. One of the main reasons is that some women have no financial resources which lead to the shrinking family income. Economic problems have led to domestic violence, however, this problem has yet to be resolved, however, seeking help for “family matters” is still a taboo in Japanese society. As a result, we should take proactive measures such as establishing emergency shelters for those who have suffered domestic violence to help women escape from the shadow pandemic.

At the same time, because of the increase in the female unemployment rate, the financial burden of the family has also led to an increase in the suicide rate. This is social violence against women.

Sexual violence

From Indian perspective, sexual violence is a big problem.

There are many reasons for the Washington posted delves into the root cause of the sexual violence in India. Some of the reasons is appalling such as wearing the dress with a teaser is refers to himself in trouble is to encourage victims to compromise and even persuade victims to marry raped. Moreover, India’s legal process is quite slow.

There are many main reasons. First, this dues to the lack of policewomen. Research shows that if there are more policewoman, women will be more willing to report rape case. Second, inadequate number of police. An article on the institution, thinks that India did not have enough the police to protect ordinary citizens, while the existing police often lack basic investigation skills training and equipment. Thirdly, the lack of public safety. Women generally lack of protection. Rape occurred on the bus, even the Indian authorities have said India is unsafe for women in public places. The fourth is not convicted. In India have reported the case of rape, only less than 26% of the cases have to convict prisoner. Last but not least, low status of women. For poor families, daughter’s dowry is a family burden greatly. Due to sex-selective abortions and female infanticide, India is the world’s one of the lowest populations of female to male ratio. In India, the son of the treatment is better than daughters, forever and easier to get the chance to receive education, so employment prospects are better.

India also presented some laws to prevent sexual violence. In 2017, police in utter Pradesh’s chief minister about adidas tower when he took office, he decided to establish “Romeo” team to solve the problem of female security, however, this doesn’t make sense. Experts said that the culture of impunity in the criminal justice system is weak, the government’s measures and legal trial are powerless. As a result, India is eager to find some effective methods to solve these problems.

law and advice

The Asia-Pacific region lags behind the world in the level of legal protection for women, as well as the frequency and intensity of government voices on gender inequality. This stems from the traditions and religions of the Asia-pacific region, which, as we have mentioned, cannot be changed in a short period of time. So we propose that the law be used to protect women’s rights more effectively.

1.For developing countries, legal policies in favour of women should be established. Such as health products tax exemption, marriage compensation regulations, etc.

2.Improve laws and regulations on sexual violence (including marital sexual violence), cold violence, religious acts that injure women, abuse of women, and killing women, so as to simplify filing procedures, diversify forms of evidence collection, and make case handling process private. To make sure women speak up for themselves.

3.Increase the punishment of violence and illegal!! It is also suggested that special punishments should be carried out for some special crimes (such as bracelets for the perpetrators of symbolic violence, whipping, etc.)

entry.title: something about the first term in high school
entry.content:
关于高中第一学期

SOMETHING ABOUT THE FIRST TERM IN HIGH SCHOOL

个人总结

用三到五个形容词总结和表现出自己的特点。总结具体内容包含我在这一学期的成功之处、需继续努力之处、得到的帮助、今后的目标、要采取的措施、以及希望得到的帮助等。

首先，我想用内向、慢热和乐于助人这三个词来描述我自己。这一学期中我的成功之处有第一次在监督下连续做了一个月的家务，又学会了几首新的古筝曲，坚持参加了一个学期的管乐团训练和计算机社团等。需要努力之处是要提高课业成绩，提升学习效率，增强体育锻炼，学会合理安排作息时间等。得到的帮助有老师同学耐心地帮助我解题，同学在我临时有事的情况下帮助我向老师请假和交作业并且把笔记借给我誊抄，班外同学抽空协助我完成的排球考试等。今后的其中一个目标是所有科目成绩都达到A，我要采取的措施有合理安排学习计划和作息时间，自觉学习。希望得到的帮助是他人的适当监督。

Personal review

You may use three to five adjectives to summarize your performance. The detailed content may include your success, the help you got, your goal in the future, methods you will take and so on.

First of all, I think I am an introverted girl. I am not willing to chat with people who are not familiar with me. However, I am always willing to help people in need. In this term, I succeeded in doing housework for a whole month for the first time. I also could play some new songs by guzheng. Moreover, I attended every lessons held by computer science club and the orchestra of school. There is something that I can improve. I did not try my best in academic achievements so I will work harder. Also, I should do more exercise. This can be solved by arranging my time properly. I need to overcome these problems. I did get a lot of help in this term. My teachers and classmates helped me with my assignments patiently. My classmates helped me hand in my homework and lent their notes to me when meetings held by school and our lessons were the same time. One of my friends in another class helped me pass the volleyball exam. Finally, one of my goals is to achieve A in all the subjects. As a result, I need to learn how to make a reasonable plan. The help I want is the proper supervision of others.

课外活动（社团、志愿者活动等）

请列出活动名称，详细内容建议包含活动目的、过程、体会、反思及未来计划等。

本学期我主要参加了三个社团，分别是:管乐团、计算机社团和视听艺术社团。其中,管乐团和计算机社团活动更多。参加管乐团的原因是我对音乐有着浓厚的兴趣。在管乐团，我挑战了6天学会从未接触过的长号，目的是为升旗仪式伴奏。到目前为止，我已经参与了3次升旗仪式伴奏。这让我明白了一切皆有可能和努力会有回报。以后我也会坚持积极练习长号。参加计算机社团的原因是我对计算机了解较少，希望扩充知识面。计算机社团的活动形式为授课。通过一学期的课程，我的确拓宽了自己的视野，提升了自己的能力。但是，如果我完成社团活动的作业更积极，那么我应该会有更多收获。此外，我还搭建了自己的网站，目的是记录分享自己的生活。网站搭建的成功给我带来了很大的成就感和喜悦。但是我的更新速度太慢，所以我决定在寒假中多更新。我还参加了一个一周一次的读书分享会，目的是与会中成员交流好书，同时释放压力、放松心情。我认为所有的成员都在分享前认真做了准备，的确是希望与大家分享。我也已经分享了《自控力》这本书的两个章节，希望可以从生活中帮助大家。我以后还会坚持这项活动，从分享中获益。

Extracurricular activities

You may list the activities you have participated in and state what you have learned from these activities.

This term, I took part in three clubs: the orchestra of school, computer science club and audio-visual art club. Among them, the orchestra of school and computer club held more activities than the audio-visual art club. The reason for joining the orchestra is that I am interested in music. In the orchestra, I learned how to play trombone which I had never played before for only six days to accompany the flag raising ceremony. So far, I have attended flag raising ceremony accompaniment for three times. These activities make me understand that everything is possible. In the future, I will continue to actively practice playing trombone. The reason for joining the computer science club is that I knew little about computer science before and hoped to improve my knowledge. The main activities held by this club are taking lessons. Through the course of one whole term, I really broadened my horizons and improved my ability. However, if I had finished my homework more actively, I might have got more skills. In addition, I set up my own website to record and share my life. The success of website construction has brought me a great sense of achievement and joy. However, my update speed is too slow. As a result, I decided to write more articles during the winter holiday. I also took part in a weekly reading seminar. The purpose of the meeting is to share good books with others, release pressure and relax. I think all members had made preparations before sharing the books. I have also shared two chapters of the book named the willpower instinct. I think this book can help people develop good habits. I will continue taking part in this activity in the future and benefit from book sharing.
